video.title: R Programming Tutorial - Learn the Basics of Statistical Computing
video.description:
Learn the R programming language in this tutorial course. This is a hands-on overview of the statistical programming language R, one of the most important tools in data science.

💻Course Files: https://drive.google.com/drive/folders/15U8WjVKbYXaq6N6Wb_6bCr9QZ1DwCkAO

💻 Course created by Barton Poulson from datalab.cc.
🔗 Check out the datalab.cc YouTube channel: https://www.youtube.com/user/datalabcc
🔗 Watch more free data science courses at http://datalab.cc/

⭐️ Course Contents ⭐️
⌨️ (0:00:00) Welcome
⌨️ (0:02:20) Installing R
⌨️ (0:07:17) RStudio
⌨️ (0:11:52) Packages
⌨️ (0:19:16) plot()
⌨️ (0:27:49) Bar Charts
⌨️ (0:32:10) Histograms
⌨️ (0:39:44) Scatterplots
⌨️ (0:44:39) Overlaying Plots
⌨️ (0:52:30) summary()
⌨️ (0:55:49) describe()
⌨️ (1:00:17) Selecting Cases
⌨️ (1:06:14) Data Formats
⌨️ (1:21:39) Factors
⌨️ (1:28:34) Entering Data
⌨️ (1:34:18) Importing Data
⌨️ (1:42:29) Hierarchical Clustering
⌨️ (1:49:35) Principal Components
⌨️ (1:59:16) Regression
⌨️ (2:08:36) Next Steps

--

Learn to code for free and get a developer job: https://www.freecodecamp.org

Read hundreds of articles on programming: https://www.freecodecamp.org/news

topLevelComment.text:
If you are a Windows user, and have run into an issue with importing around 1:38:45 , producing an error that reads something like: "Error: '\U' used without hex digits in character string starting ""C:\U", the problem occurs because of the use of single forward slashes (I'm just learning this myself). One unfun but useful workaround is to just double the forward slashes like so: \\

Really clear and useful video but that might be an important point for non-Mac users.

replies.author: e b
replies.text: Had the same issue, but I found a brute force method that can be used later, tho not very elegant. Manually import the selected file through File>Import Dataset>From text. The table opens in a new tab, but if you look at the console, the location of the imported file is documented there in the needed format. Copy and paste it into the import() function. This source location can be used in read.csv(path) as well.

topLevelComment.author: Mr SpLiT
topLevelComment.text:
Would have been nice for the "tutor" to actually use filenames corresponding with those in the video.

Also, content of said tutorial files does not actually match those of the tutor's in the video.

And finally, the shortcut keys used by the tutor do not work with the "latest" Windows version of the GUI - the GUI itself being seemed to have been developed in 1987 and never updated.

These are such amateur mistakes that should have been checked and corrected before publishing this video.

I've conducted plenty of IT training over the last 30 years and I always ensure all the course content is correct.

So on that basis I'll be looking elsewhere for a beginners tutorial as I have no faith nor confidence in the "tutor" of this video.

replies.author: Channel AyahMizaruni
replies.text:
To everyone having trouble finding the files: 
Yes, they are still there, they have just been renamed. You find them in the google drive link in this videos description next to "Course Files".
The naming has been slightly changed compared to what you see in the video. 
There is no folder "R01_Course_Files" anymore, instead the example files used in this video are found directly in the downloaded folder called CourseFiles.
Also the names of the files have been simplified. 
So for example instead of "R01_3_2_Barcharts.R" the file is now simply called "Barcharts.R"

topLevelComment.author: Chris Cockrell
topLevelComment.text:
Great understanding.
0:50 R is the heaviest used software in Data Science. (Free, Vector Ops, Community, packages)
ctrl +Enter runs the line from the script.
16:20 Installing Pacman
21:00 Plot(x,y) is a scatter plot of data, but adapts to the type of data.
?plot then look at help
Bar charts are for counts with category data is.
Histograms are for (shape, gaps, outliers, symmetry) seeing interval data.
scatterplot (linear, spread, outlier, correlation) 
Dataframes and lists
1:43:00 Modeling Data (Heirarchical Clustering, set number of k groups, measures of distance, Divisive (all in one group then start spliting apart) vs agglomative -all apart then add together).
Principle components (PCA) - less noise, fewer unhelpful variables implies more meaning.  1:50:20 Shadows. 
2 variables. linear.  regression.  But we look at the perpendicular distance to regression lines, not vertical.  Collapse distance.  Rotate (transform data).  2D to 1D.  Hopefully it is important information.
Regression - stepwise, forward, lars, lasso

replies.author: datalabcc
replies.text:
This is Bart Poulson, who made the video. Those file links are only valid if (a) you're on a Mac; and (b) you saved the file to your desktop. If you're on a Windows or Linux computer, or if you've saved the file somewhere else, then you would need a different path. Often, you can get that by control-clicking on your file and copying the file path.

As a separate issue, you would need to include the file extension, .csv, in the command, as well. rio_csv <- import("~/Desktop/mbb.csv")

topLevelComment.author: HiGh ArT AlErT
topLevelComment.text: Man you haven't explained why to unload packages? More packages gives more functionality. Why not keep them loaded?

replies.author: macadamia9
replies.text: @datalabcc That makes complete sense... Thank you!

replies.author: HiGh ArT AlErT
replies.text: @datalabcc Thank you. That helps.

replies.author: datalabcc
replies.text: This is Bart Poulson, who made the video. There are two main reasons to unload packages when you're done with an analysis. First, sometimes two packages will have different functions with the same names, which can create confusion for the program. Second, reproducibility and the ability to share you code work much better if you start fresh every time and know exactly what went into the analysis. Otherwise, it's a little too easy to lose track of what functions come from which packages. I totally clean out R after every analysis.

topLevelComment.author: Coop
topLevelComment.text:
Importing Datasets For Windows :)
1. Find the file path/LOCATION for your file (right click on it and go to "Properties" it'll be on the "General" tab)
2. Copy this and paste it into R in place of the file path provided in the lesson
3. Change all of the backslashes "\" to forward slashes "/"
5. Delete the tilde "~" at the beginning
6. Use Ctrl + Enter to run!

Example:

How the lesson comes (AKA: MAC version):
rio_csv  <-  import("~/Desktop/mbb.csv")
head(rio_csv)

Change to:
rio_csv  <-  import("C:/Users/username_000/Desktop/mbb.csv")
head(rio_csv)

Original Windows Path:
C:\Users\username_000\Desktop\mbb.csv

If you DO NOT change the forward slashes to backslashes you will continue to get an error message.

This might be a bit overkill of an explanation, but I saw some people were confused by it (as was I) so hopefully it'll help someone!

topLevelComment.author: Nikolas M
topLevelComment.text: Recent data has seen python becoming the number 1 language by a big margin, particularly because future data science modules are expected to continue being developed for python and discontinue in R

replies.author: datalabcc
replies.text: @Nikolas M Hi Nikolas, my guess is that the preferences for software and languages in finance mirror those in the rest of data science: R would be relatively common for statistical analysis and Python would be relatively common for machine learning. Tasks like credit scoring, fraud detection, and algorithmic trading will rely very heavily on machine learning, so I imagine that Python would be more common there. But in terms of analysis – that is, trying to understand the trends and not just predict them – it is possible that something like R is more common. Really, you'd do best to find a few people who do what you're interested in and then ask them what they use. (And it's worth remembering that ANYBODY working in finance should be completely fluent in Microsoft Excel. Really.) As for universities, I don't know, but if the program has "data science" in the title, it will probably emphasize machine learning and Python, whereas if it has something like "financial analysis" in the title, it may be R. But take a look at programs that are interesting to you!

replies.author: Nikolas M
replies.text: @datalabcc Mr. Poulson thank you both for your video lectures and for your response; I think you've made a very solid point in the distinction between the two. I have two questions if you don't mind. 1) Which language do you believe is more prominent in the sector of financial analysis? 2) Most masters I've seen in data science choose python over R. Do you happen to know a solid University favoring R over python for its curriculum? Many thanks

replies.author: datalabcc
replies.text:
This is Barton Poulson, who created the video course. You're absolutely right that Python's popularity has been growing and that it passed R a couple years ago on software for data science. Python is a wonderful language and I strongly to encourage anyone working in data science to learn Python in addition to R. But I think the change in popularity has more to do with a shift in the practice of data science, where there is a much greater emphasis on machine learning (including neural networks and deep learning) than there was a few years ago. I would generally recommend Python for anyone doing that kind of machine learning (although R is able to do most of it, too). 


But I don't think R is going to disappear because it tends to fill a different niche than R. R is extraordinarily well adapted for data ANALYSIS, more so than Python, I believe. For example, I'm an academic psychologist and I don't know a single psychological researcher who uses Python for data analysis but I know a great number who use R. The same is true in many other fields. 


I expect R to stick around and continue thriving with its intended audience, just as Bash and FORTRAN still excel with their intended audiences.

replies.author: datalabcc
replies.text: All of them. Anybody who touches data in any form should be able to use spreadsheets like Excel or Google Sheets because that's how data is often supplied from clients and it's often how they will want it back. I know billion dollar companies that run exclusively on Excel. I do consulting for multinational finance companies who send me their data in Excel. Every nonprofit I have worked with has used Excel. Like any tool, spreadsheets have their ideal use cases where they shine: sharing small data sets, browsing data, integrating data and graphics. Plus, they're not hard to use. Even if you're not using them in data science work, per se, you can still use them to track your hours, prepare invoices, plan projects, and so on. Any good data scientist can benefit from spreadsheets.

topLevelComment.author: Just Me
topLevelComment.text: 2 questions on hierarchical clustering: 1. Why was hclust implied as divisive method? It is actually agglomorative. 2. Why wasn't the data scaled beforehand? The Euclidean distance is going to be skewed by larger value variables.

replies.author: datalabcc
replies.text: I made the video and you are correct on both counts. While hierarchical clustering in general can be either agglomerative or divisive, the hclust function is, as you point out, agglomerative. I had never paid attention to that before because I believe it usually doesn't make a substantial difference in the results, but thank you for pointing it out. You are also correct that scaling beforehand would have been appropriate. I glossed over that step in the interest of keeping things simpler but that was a poor choice. I'm creating new versions of the exercises (although I don't know how long until I record them) but I will make a point of including that critical step. Again, thanks for pointing it out.

replies.author: Shrinivas Dharma
replies.text: @datalabcc Thanks Bart. Problem resolved.

replies.author: datalabcc
replies.text:
The first step, which I believe you already did, is to install pacman: install.packages("pacman")


The second step is to load pacman. You can use either the base command: require("pacman") or use pacman to load itself: pacman::p_load(pacman)


Then you can use pacman to load other packages: p_load(ggplot2)


Bart

replies.author: Erwin Schrödinger
replies.text: Wow! I remember that one too. I hadn't thought about it for ages. I'm probably older than most on this thread. I used to program in Fortran and also assembly language when needed on the old IBM mainframes. At that time APL fascinated me when I heard about it. I wanted to do something with it but it was never quite right for what I wanted to do. When I saw your mention of APL,  I looked it up on Wikipedia. There it says "APL has formed the basis of, or influenced, the following languages: " and then it lists many languages including S. But S, of course, is the direct parent of R.  So you're right. APL did lead to R. Also Matlab and Mathematica according to Wiki.  This is what happens. Things change. I'm learning R now because I'm tired of the menus on SSPS for the statistical stuff I do. One can use R to extend SPSS anyway, so it's a very important thing to learn for anyone doing any statistics these days. And, in case you may wonder, though Fortran is very fast and there are new Fortrans available, I'll never program in that again. I used to love it but R is much easier to deal with. I used to use Fortran for statistical models of biophysical calculations I was making. But if R was available then, I would have dropped Fortran in a minute. Fortran is still useful in physics, at least that's what I read.  It's wicked fast though compiled C# (or ##) is about as fast now. I'm still a beginner in "R, which is why I'm looking at this video, but already I love it.
